doc.after: Seventeen confirmed examples are known.[1] An additional monument, at Takalik Abaj in Guatemala, is a throne that may have been carved from a colossal head.[36] This is the only known example outside of the Olmec heartland on the Gulf Coast of Mexico.[37] Possible fragments of additional colossal heads have been recovered at San Lorenzo and at San Fernando in Tabasco.[31] Crude colossal stone heads are also known in the Southern Maya area where they are associated with the potbelly style of sculpture.[38] Although some arguments have been made that they are pre-Olmec, these latter monuments are generally believed to be influenced by the Olmec style of sculpture.[39]
